title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: It was very professional and friendly but a very long process with different PIs and MDs. They seemed well prepared and knew almost what I did prior and what my future role was.
Interview Questions: Most of the questions came from my publications and how that would allow me to take over the new projects.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: 1 on 1 interview with postdoc that I was going to work with. Discussed my experience, career goals, and research interests. They explained what they were working on and the general focus of the lab.
Interview Questions: What lab experience do you have?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions: Very standard. Started with a job talk, then one on one interviews with lab members as well as neighbouring professors. Overall a very positive experience and would happily go through it again! Was very fun.
Interview Questions: Why have you chosen our lab over others? How did you discover our lab?

title: Research Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: First, I had a screener set up with senior HR member. This was set up over email and was received over a phone call. Then, I had an initial first round interview with the direct supervisor
Interview Questions: What is your research experience?

title: Interactive Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Started with an initial phone screen, a thirty minute interview with the hiring manager, and two take home tests. I received positive feedback after the first take home test, was given another just to annotate code, submitted it and then heard absolutely nothing from the hiring manager or the recruiter. Their expectations around theses tests are pretty unclear and I honestly don’t know how much effort they expect you to put in for each part of the process. I did what I could in the little free time I had, even just some feedback on the last one would have been helpful even if it wasn’t passable for them. Honestly if they want to attract good candidates they need to immensely improve the hiring process. They clearly couldn’t find anyone to meet their vague standards because the job got reposted recently. I ended up accepting a job elsewhere with better candidate experience and benefits and withdrew my application because I had heard nothing in over a month.
Interview Questions: What kind of development work are you interested in doing?

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: No response at all despite filling out the necessary forms and information to the recruiter that reached out.  Was waiting to hear back for weeks and no response after follow up either
Interview Questions: Did not respond after initial contact

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed for an intern position. There was a short phone interview  with the lab manager before the formal interview. Then, during the formal interview, I talked with several postdoc about their projects and why I am interested in the research that they were working on.
Interview Questions:
why do you want to be a research assistant?
how much do you know the projects we are working on?

title: Public Services Librarian Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: Accepted an invitation to interview for a newly-created position and spoke with the hiring team, but after a month passed with no follow up I reached out and was told they were going with other candidates. This is against Harvard University's interviewing policies which generally call for a direct phone call to candidates who have progressed to the interview stage of the process.
Interview Questions: What interests you about reference services?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: Very easy, the whole process is very interactive and welcoming. The Pi is very nice and the lab members are very supportive . Overall it was a pleasant interview. I think I gain a lot in this process.
Interview Questions: What’s your vision and goals

title: Video Producer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Cambridge, MA) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: The scheduling process of straightforward. The interview was with HR. The interview itself was fairly structured and pleasant, covering basic questions that are open-ended related to experiences and skills required by the job.
Interview Questions: What was your past experience in online course production/video editing?

title: Data Consultant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: Quick phone call asking about technical skills pertaining to their research. Ask how you would solve certain issues based on knowledge of code. Conversation about future plans and how many hours that you can commit.
Interview Questions: How would you solve this issue?

title: EContent Developer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: 30 minute phone call to clarify CV; I explained my background and experience; several job-specific questions were asked; 30 minute phone call to clarify CV; I explained my background and experience; several job-specific questions were asked
Interview Questions: Tell us about your background

title: FP&A Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very standard - primarily getting to know you and then a couple of behavioral based questions at the end.  Not too much prep time is necessary
Interview Questions: Have you ever had to work under someone who wasn’t very good at communicating? What happened?

title: Biostatistician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: HR interview (regular questions) lasted 15 mins. Phone interview with the manager (awesome person). A whole day of phone of interviews with different teams. I wasn't asked anything technical in any of the interviews.
Interview Questions: Describe a project you worked on. Be prepared to tell a story.

title: Program Operations Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted a few days after I initially applied online by the talent acquisition manager.  I had a phone screen that went really well, and I was told I was among 3 people who made it to the phone screen.  I then had an interview with the hiring manager and 4 other colleagues that the new employee would be working with.  I thought the interviews went well,  and I followed up in email after to thank everyone for their time.

Weeks went by and I heard nothing.  I then sent a follow up email to the talent acquisition manager asking about the status of the position, and she never responded.  I find it very rude and disrespectful to not even respond to emails and let the applicant know that they have decided to move in another direction.  I understand not emailing every applicant, however when you have it narrowed down and conduct multiple interviews with someone, the respectful thing to do is to let the candidate know either way.   It has turned me off to ever applying for to another position with Harvard.
Interview Questions: Describe a challenge you faced in your current/previous role and how you overcame it.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School
Interview Descriptions: The process was a walkthrough of the laboratory and questions about the lab. Simple and straightforward. Additional references were requested after the interview and the interviewer wanted an extra copy of my resume.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Computation Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Aug 2020

1 week to decide to go ahead with the application or not. HR team is a bit slow though, they sent the offer letter almost 1 month after giving the verbal commitment.
Interview Questions: Tell e about yourself? Describe the project which you are proud of.  How are you great fit for this role.

title: Research Assistant II Interview

title: Administrative Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process was fast for me. Pretty typical interview. Had to go in twice to meet with different people. Although I don't think the interview prepared me for the job I actually ended up working.
Interview Questions: Describe working with a difficult person.

title: Product Owner Interview

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard Medical School

nice lab tour without any confused and tough questions after figuring out an project within 2 days(during the weekends days)

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2013
Interview Descriptions: The lab PI responded my email inquiry for lab postdoc position almost right away. The interview was offered about two weeks after the first email. Then it took 3-4 weeks to start the interview. The interview took half a day including an one hour presentation summarizing the phd work and one on one meetings with 4-5 junior and senior lab members.
Interview Questions: what's your career goal and why our lab fits your goal?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: This really depends on the Principal Investigator your interview with, their needs, and your previous qualifications, mostly publishing record and technical experience. First contact always is by email, then a skype interview, followed by an invited talk, and a group interview as well. Sometimes this requires talking to other postdocs and grad students in an informal setting (e.g. during lunch). If they liked your style then you will get an offer on the project you will develop, and afterwards you will be on board to do hard work all the way.
Interview Questions: Providing your perspective on a topic might be key if you are asked to give one, because it shows personal preferences, self-motivation, and career orientation. They also might ask what you personal projects/goals would be if you get involved to a lab. Sometimes very detailed technical questions do arise, so be prepared for it.

Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Many administrative support professionals come from other Harvad institutions and/or start off at HMS as temporary employees. The interview process can take several weeks. The transition from a temporary employee to a permanent employee can take months. Keep in mind, the department and respective managers have to align positions and compensation with Harvard HR plus the HUCTW Union for all administrative support positions.  When interviewing, prospective administrative professional candidates mostly meet/greet other administrative professionals; they're extensively interviewed by management members but not my prospective office administration co-workers.
Interview Questions: Why would you be the best candidate for this position?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: The interview process usually starts with a presentation of your graduate work followed by one to one interviews with people in the lab including one with PI. Usually people will talk about their own research projects and pros and cons about the lab. In the end, you usually will get chance to talk to the PI and discuss about the possible projects in the lab.
Interview Questions: What is the scientific project yo would like to carry out in the lab?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Apr 2011
Interview Descriptions: In the morning, (at 9 am) meeting with PI for 1 hour, presentation for 1 hour, meeting with individuals for 20-30 min per each in the group, lunch with PI and group members for 1 hour, more meeting with the rest of group members, final meeting with PI
Interview Questions: why do you want to join? what project do you want?

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 3+ months. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Dec 2010
Interview Descriptions: Very stringent - multiple interviews with multiple levels of people, even for bottom rung positions. Only ~ 3% of applicants get a job.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with difficult people? (The question should be how do you deal with entitled people who treat you like crap?)

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard Medical School (Boston, MA) in Sept 2008
Interview Descriptions: e-mail contact and then interview request and hired
Interview Questions: there was not that difficult interview process or question

title: Research Associate Interview

Interview Descriptions: Write a proposal and discuss with the hiring manager. Try to bring your own fellowship or grant.
